case_vignette:
A newborn fullterm female is noted to have a patch of hair loss, prominent leg veins, and shortened fingers at birth. Prenatal course was unremarkable. Physical examination reveals an extensive large ulcerated atrophic plaque on the scalp with surrounding peripheral hair, brachydactyly of index fingers, and lacy reticulated violaceous patches on the right thigh and calf.  The patient is a 1-month-old female.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a patch of hair loss, prominent veins on my legs, and shortened index fingers.
Have you noticed any changes in skin color or texture in the areas of hair loss?
Yes, there is a large area on my scalp that is ulcerated and has a thinned-out appearance.
Do you have any history of skin cancer in your family?
I'm not aware of any history of skin cancer in my family.
Have you been exposed to any chemicals or radiation, especially at work or during leisure activities?
I have not been exposed to any chemicals or radiation.
Has any biopsy been done on the affected areas, especially the scalp? If so, what were the results?
No biopsy has been done on the affected areas.

Given the presence of ulceration and a thinned-out appearance of the scalp combined with hair loss and other deformities, I recommend a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. However, have you experienced any recent weight loss, fatigue, or other systemic symptoms?
No, I have not experienced any weight loss, fatigue, or other systemic symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome (Gorlin Syndrome)
